courses.subject: HSOC
courses.title: Nutrition for Public Health
courses.description: Description Public health nutrition is the promotion and maintenance of nutrition-related health and wellbeing of populations through organized efforts and informed choices of society. To be effective, public health nutritionists must first connect the principles of nutritional science to the realm of public health practice in ways that emphasize the multi-factorial origins of actual nutritional problems in modern societies. In this course, students will be introduced to various essential elements of food and nutritional sciences. The current nutrition issues at both local and global levels will be discussed. The application of these on promoting nutrition health of the population will be illustrated.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For TPg students in Master of Public Health.
courses.course_syllabus:
| Introduction to Public Health Nutrition |
| --- |
| Fundamentals (I) Basics of Nutritional Science |
| Fundamentals (II) Nutrition across the lifespan |
| Fundamentals (III) Nutrition Assessment in Individuals and Populations |
| Issues associated with over-nutrition |
| Issues associated with undernutrition |
| Food safety and major nutritional concerns in the modern world |
| Promoting Healthy Nutrition |
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Gibney MJ, Margetts BM, Kearney JM and Arab L. Public Health Nutrition, Blackwell Publishing, 2004 ISBN 0-632-05627-4

2. Diet, Nutrition and the Prevention of Chronic Diseases WHO Technical Report No. 916, 2003 [www.who.int/dietphysicalactivity/publications/trs916/download/en](http://www.who.int/dietphysicalactivity/publications/trs916/download/en)

3. Truswell A. Stewart. ABC of nutrition, BMJ: London, 2003 ISBN 0727916645

courses.subject: HSOC
courses.title: Medical Sociology
courses.description: The course provides an opportunity to students to understand issues of health care in society from sociological perspectives. Individuals are social beings who are subject to the influence of social forces and interpersonal relationships. Concerning health and illness, other than the pathological elements, the sick person is inevitably affected by a wide range of social variables and personal behaviour. The macroscopic and microscopic perspectives in understanding the issues of health and illness in context are important in the course of service delivery and policy making.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For TPg student in –
Master of Public Health
MSc/PgD in Epidemiology and Biostatistics
courses.learning_outcomes:
Student should be able to:
1. analyse concepts and ideas about health and illness in context
2. suggest effects of human agency, social groups and social institutions in shaping individuals' health and illness behaviour
3. synthesize sociological perspectives in understanding issues of health and health care delivery in society
courses.course_syllabus:
| 1. Getting Started: Introduction to Sociological Perspectives and Concepts 2. Sociological Understanding on Health and Illness 3. Discussion Tutorial |
| --- |
| 1. Responses to Health and Illness 2. Discussion Tutorial |
| 1. Experiencing Health and Illness 2. Interactions between Professionals and Clients in Health Care Settings 3. Discussion Tutorial |
| Reading Week |
| 1. Social Patterning on Health and Illness 2. Discussion Tutorial |
| 1. Disease Label, Medicine and Social Control 2. Discussion Tutorial |
| 1. Health Care in Political and Economic Contexts 2. Course Summary |
courses.required_readings: Scambler, G. (Ed.) (2008). *Sociology as* *applied to medicine*. Edinburgh: Saunders.
courses.recommended_readings:
Bird, C. E., Conrad, P., Fremont, A. M., & Timmermans, S. (Eds.) (2010). ***Handbook of medical sociology.*** Nashville: Vanderbilt University Press.

Cockerham, C. W. (2010). [*The new Blackwell companion to medical sociology.*](https://julac.hosted.exlibrisgroup.com/primo-explore/search?query=null%2C%2CThe%20New%20Blackwell%20Companion%20to%20Medical%20Sociology%2CAND&vid=HKU&mode=advanced) Oxford, UK: Wiley‐Blackwell.

Cockerham, C. W., Dingwall, R., & Quah, S. R. (Eds.) (2014). *The Wiley Blackwell encyclopedia of health, illness, behavior, and society*. Chichester, West Sussex: Wiley Blackwell.

Gabe, J., & Monaghan, L. F. (Eds.) (2013). *Key concepts in medical sociology*. London: Sage.

Other reading material will be given at the beginning of the course.

courses.subject: HSOC
courses.title: Health for Special Population
courses.description: Health needs vary according to characteristics of population. This course underlies key health issues and needs among different population subgroups. Specifically, health needs of special and vulnerable population groups would be explored and discussed. Features related to planning, implementation and evaluation for programs target to special health needs would be highlighted.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For TPg students in Master of Public Health
courses.learning_outcomes:
Student should be able to:
1. explore and understand different health needs among population subgroups.
2. apply public health principles to analyze and evaluate major health needs and issues faced by different population subgroups.
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to the course outline provided by course treacher.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course treacher.

courses.subject: HSOC
courses.title: Medical Anthropology
courses.description: Medical Anthropology is the sub-discipline of social anthropology that examines the social processes and cultural representations of health, illness and the health care practices. Using primarily qualitative and ethnographic methods, medical anthropologists specifically examine: 1) the development of systems of medical knowledge and medical care, 2) the relationship between healthcare provider and patients 3) the integration of alternative medical systems in culturally diverse environments, 4) the interaction of social, environmental and biological factors which influence health and illness, and 5) the impact of biomedicine and biomedical technologies in non-Western settings. This course will draw upon lectures and readings to illustrate the applicability of medical anthropology to current public health research.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Public Health
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Have a grounding in key topics and perspectives in medical anthropology.
• Be able to give a basic overview of the historical background and theoretical contributions of medical anthropology. Be familiar with the current directions of medical anthropology in public health.
• Be able to describe the applicability of medical anthropology towards public health research or public health interventions.
• Equip participants with a basic understanding of the types of research skills used in medical anthropology and to understand the methodological issues in health-related research.
courses.course_syllabus: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teacher
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teacher

courses.subject: HSOC
courses.title: Lecture Series in Non-Communicable Diseases as Public Health Concerns
courses.description: This course aims to Introduce to students how non-communicable diseases (NCDs) become a major public health concern in the past decades, the trend of common NCDs, and prevention strategies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Public Health
courses.learning_outcomes: After the course, students will be able to examine different health promotion strategies and approach to minimize the risk factors and enhance the protective to combat the growing epidemics of NCD.
courses.course_syllabus:
| Impact of rapid urbanization and socio-economic burden on health |
| --- |
| Mental health across lifespan |
| Poverty and health |
| Dietary prevention for non-communicable diseases |
| Patient self-management for non-communicable diseases |
| Physical activity, people, and the environment Part 1 & Part II |
| Prevention of NCD amongst marginalized population and vulnerable group |
| Group exercise on specific topics |
| Group exercise preparation for presentation |
| Blocked time for problem solving questions |
| **Presentation and assessment** |
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teacher

courses.subject: HSOC
courses.title: Social Marketing Methods
courses.description: The course aims at providing participants an overview of social marketing as an approach to health promotion. The course will cover key concepts and elements of social marketing, as well as the benchmark criteria for a social marketing initiative. The course will be conducted in a combined format of lecture and workshop. Examples of application of social marketing in health promotion will be illustrated in the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Public Health
courses.learning_outcomes: The course aims at providing participants an overview of social marketing as an approach to health promotion.
courses.course_syllabus: The course will cover key concepts and elements of social marketing, as well as the benchmark criteria for a social marketing initiative. Examples of application of social marketing in health promotion will be illustrated in the course
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teacher

courses.subject: HSOC
courses.title: Motivational Interviewing
courses.description: Motivational interviewing is one of the new but promising approaches in counselling clients when treating their lifestyle problems and disease. It is a directive and client-centred counselling style to elicit clients’ awareness to current problems and readiness to change their behaviour. The course will train participants to conduct motivational interview.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Course Objectives

(1) Understand and recognize the various stages in the stage of change model and its implication to our interventions

(2) Explore the practice of motivational interviewing, including resistance and motivation for change, change talk, commitment to change etc.

(3) Gaining experiences, competency and confidence in conducting motivational interviewing through observational learning and skill-building practices

(4) Review and examine how motivational interviewing can be used across different work context.

Competencies

(1) Ability to support, build and improve your therapeutic relationship with your service users

(2) Ability to implement effective communication skills that can help you motivate your service users toward a change in thinking and behaviour
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Review on stage of change theory and elements of motivational interviewing (MI)

2. Identify and practice of MI phase 1 skills and strategies

3. Change talk and handling resistance

4. MI phase 2 skills and strategies, summary and closure
courses.recommended_readings:
MI Learner’s Manual (to be distributed in workshop)

Miller, W.R. & Rollnick, S. (2002). Motivational interviewing: Preparing people for change (2nd ed.) New York: Guilford Press.

Rosengren, D. (2009). Building Motivational Interviewing Skills: a practitioner workbook, New York: Guildford Press.

courses.subject: HSOC
courses.title: Practicum / Project on Health Promotion and Health Education
courses.description: Enables students to apply the principles, knowledge and skills learned in an academic setting through a supervised field training experience in a public health setting and the preparation of a monograph embodying original research applicable to health promotion and health education.
